justification: Presents with fever, conjunctivitis, cervical lymphadenopathy, and hand erythema, but pyuria is not typical.}, {diagnosis: Adenovirus infection

justification: Can cause fever, conjunctivitis, cervical lymphadenopathy, and sometimes hand-foot-and-mouth disease (which can present with hand erythema), but pyuria is not common.}, {diagnosis: Urinary tract infection (UTI) with concurrent viral illness
justification: Explains the pyuria and fever. The other symptoms suggest a concurrent viral illness, which could be caused by many viruses.}, {diagnosis: Infectious mononucleosis (Epstein-Barr virus)

justification: Can cause fever, cervical lymphadenopathy, and sometimes conjunctivitis, but hand erythema and pyuria are not typical.}, {diagnosis: Streptococcal pharyngitis (strep throat) with atypical presentation
justification: Can cause fever, cervical lymphadenopathy, and sometimes conjunctivitis, but hand erythema and pyuria are not typical.}, {diagnosis: Measles
justification: Can cause fever, conjunctivitis, and cervical lymphadenopathy, but hand erythema and pyuria are not typical.}, {diagnosis: Rubella (German measles)
justification: Can cause fever, conjunctivitis, and cervical lymphadenopathy, but hand erythema and pyuria are not typical.}, {diagnosis: Systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis (sJIA)

justification: Can cause fever, rash (which could include hand erythema), and sometimes conjunctivitis, but cervical lymphadenopathy and pyuria are not typical.}, {diagnosis: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS)
justification: Can cause fever, rash (which could include hand erythema), lymphadenopathy, and conjunctivitis, but pyuria is not typical.}, {diagnosis: Leukemia
justification: Can cause fever, lymphadenopathy, and sometimes conjunctivitis, but hand erythema and pyuria are not typical.}

Rheumatic fever (less common in developed countries)
